title: Alarm Management in Drilling Operations
content: Effective alarm systems alert operators to abnormal conditions requiring action. Too many alarms cause alarm fatigueâ€”operators ignore or silence them. Follow EEMUA 191 and IADC drilling alarm guidelines: prioritize alarms, eliminate nuisance alarms, and ensure each alarm is actionable. Poor alarm management has contributed to major incidents.

scenario.story: During a well control event, 47 alarms activate within 90 seconds. The driller acknowledges and silences most of them to focus on well parameters. What alarm management failure occurred?

options.A: Driller should have addressed all alarms
options.B: Alarm flood indicates poor alarm prioritization and rationalization
options.C: This is normal during well control events

scenario.explanation: Alarm floods during critical events indicate poor alarm management. Alarms should be prioritized so only actionable, safety-critical alarms present during emergencies.

openQuestions: How many alarms does your drilling or marine control room receive per hour?
What percentage of those alarms are false, nuisance, or informational rather than actionable?
